title: 105_hr245
content: The "Small Business/Family Farm and Investment Fairness Act of 1997" is the short title of the Act. It also includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, the Act addresses the phaseout of the capital gains rate for individuals. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 addresses the maximum capital gains rate for taxpayers with a net capital gain in any taxable year. The tax imposed shall not exceed a computed tax on taxable income reduced by the net capital gain, plus a tax equal to the applicable percentage of the net capital gain. The applicable percentage for net capital gains decreases from 14% in 1997 to 4% in 2007. The net capital gain for taxable years 2007 and later can be reduced by electing to take it into account as investment income under section 163(d)(4)(B)(iii). Additionally, the minimum tax provisions under section 55(b)(1) have been amended to include new clauses. The new clause limits the maximum tax rate on net capital gain by calculating it based on the taxable excess reduced by the net capital gain and a tax equal to a certain percentage of the lesser of the net capital gain or the taxable excess. The new clause limits the maximum tax rate on net capital gain by calculating it based on the taxable excess reduced by the net capital gain and a tax equal to a certain percentage of the lesser of the net capital gain or the taxable excess. Conforming amendments include repealing section 1202 and making amendments to sections 57 and 170(e) of the Code. The amendment introduces a new clause defining the appropriate percentage for calculating capital gains tax. It also amends section 172(d) regarding the deductibility of losses and gains from sales or exchanges of capital assets for taxpayers other than corporations. The amendment modifies various sections related to gains from sales or exchanges of capital assets, including changes to section 642(c), section 643(a), section 691(c), section 871(a)(2), section 1044, and section 1445(e). Additionally, it revises section 6652 by redesignating subsections. The amendment modifies various sections related to gains from sales or exchanges of capital assets, including changes to section 642(c), section 643(a), section 691(c), section 871(a)(2), section 1044, and section 1445(e. It also revises subsections (l) and (m) as subsections (k) and (l), and makes amendments to section 7518(g)(6)(A) and section 607(h)(6)(A) by changing the applicable percentage. The table of sections for part I of subchapter P of chapter 1 is amended by striking the item relating to section 1202. Effective dates for these amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996. The amendment made by subsection (c)(10) applies to amounts paid after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. PHASEDOWN OF CAPITAL GAINS RATE FOR CORPORATIONS. Section 1201 is amended to create an alternative tax for corporations. For taxable years with a net capital gain, a tax is imposed as an alternative to the tax under sections 11, 511, and 831. The tax consists of a tax on taxable income reduced by the net capital gain and an additional tax based on a percentage of the net capital gain. The applicable percentage varies depending on the taxable year. The tax on net capital gains for taxable years from 1997 to 2009 ranged from 28% to 16%. The tax on net capital gains decreased from 28% to 14% starting in 2011 or later. The tax on net capital gains decreased from 28% to 14% starting in 2011 or later. For computation of the alternative tax, specific sections apply to different types of companies: life insurance companies (section 801(a)(2)), regulated investment companies and their shareholders (section 852(b)(3)(A) and (D)), and real estate investment trusts (section 857(b)(3)(A). The tentative minimum tax for corporations is 20% of the alternative minimum taxable income exceeding the exemption amount, reduced by the alternative minimum tax foreign tax credit. The tentative minimum tax for corporations is 20% of the alternative minimum taxable income exceeding the exemption amount, reduced by the alternative minimum tax foreign tax credit. If the percentage under section 1201(b) is less than 20 percent, the tax amount is determined based on specific calculations outlined in the legislation. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years for net capital gain or excess. Clause (iii) of section 852(b)(3)(D) is amended to define the "appropriate percentage" as the excess of 100 percent over the applicable percentage under section 1201(b). Subsection (e) of section 1445 is amended to replace "35 percent" with "the applicable percentage under section 1201(b)." The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 1996. The withholding amendment applies to amounts paid after the enactment date of this Act. A transitional rule applies to taxable years ending after December 31, 1996, and beginning on or before that date, with a tax of 28 percent on net capital gain. The tax law amendments apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 1996. For pass-thru entities, gains and losses are determined at the entity level. A tax of 35 percent is imposed on net capital gains exceeding the amount taken into account. "A pass-thru entity includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds." SEC. 4. INCREASE IN UNIFIED ESTATE AND GIFT TAX CREDIT. The unified estate and gift tax credit is increased by amending various subsections to adjust the applicable credit amount to $1,000,000. The unified estate and gift tax credit is increased to $1,000,000. Amendments are made to adjust the applicable credit amount in various subsections. The changes apply to estates of decedents dying and gifts made after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5 increases the maximum benefit under special estate tax valuation rules for certain farm real property from $750,000 to $1,000,000. This amendment applies to decedents dying after the enactment of the Act.
